「The Supreme Dao, the people below merely know of its existence;
The next best thing, they cherish and praise it;
The next, they fear it;
The next, they scorn it;
Thus, trust is insufficient, and there arises distrust.
*Ah, how they value words!*

When deeds are accomplished and affairs fulfilled,
The common folk all say, *"This is how things naturally are."*
*The Supreme Dao* refers to the age of antiquity.
*Below*, it means the realm of all under Heaven.
In the ancient times, the people of all under Heaven only knew of the sovereign’s existence,
Yet all forgot themselves within the transformations of the Dao.

Later, the people began to feel affection and praise toward the sovereign.
Again later, they began to feel fear and awe.
Again later, they began to scorn and mock.
This shows that the Way of the world declines ever downward.
When the virtue/power of the Supreme Dao wanes,
The principle of sincerity grows insufficient,
Thus the people of all under Heaven begin to harbor distrust.
This is the meaning of the *merchants’ oaths* marking the start of rebellion,
And the *gathering of the people* under the Zhou leading to suspicion.
Once the people doubt,
Yet those in governance still complacently value words,
Thus there arise proclamations, teachings, and edicts—
Does this not further deepen the people’s suspicions?
*Ah, how they value words!*—
This is the meaning of *complacency*.

In the age of the Supreme Dao,
Deeds were already accomplished,
Affairs already fulfilled,
And the people of all under Heaven silently received their blessings,
Yet did not know whence they came,
All saying, *"This is how things naturally are."*
This is what is meant by: *The imperial virtue/power is upon me—what has it to do with me?*

Since it is said that valuing words is wrong,
Yet this single phrase concludes it,
This is a lament for the present while reflecting upon the past.

**Chapter Eighteen: The Great Dao Declines**

When the Great Dao declines, there arise benevolence and righteousness;
When wisdom and cleverness emerge, there arises great deceit;
When the Six Relationships are discordant, there arise filial piety and kindness;
When the state is in chaos, there arise loyal ministers.

When the Great Dao prevails, benevolence and righteousness are inherent within it.
Once the names of benevolence and righteousness are established, the Dao grows faint.
Thus it is said: *When the Great Dao declines, there arise benevolence and righteousness.*
As if the sun of wisdom and cleverness rises,
And then deceit and falsehood flourish throughout the world.
When the Six Relationships are discordant,
Then the names of filial piety and kindness arise.
In times when the state is in chaos,
Then the names of loyal ministers arise.
These three sentences are all parables,
Illustrating the meaning of the preceding sentence.

**Chapter Nineteen: Reject Learning and Worry Ceases**

To reject learning and abandon wisdom, the people benefit a hundredfold;
To reject benevolence and abandon righteousness, the people return to filial piety and kindness;
To reject cleverness and abandon profit, thieves and robbers vanish.
These three are considered insufficient in terms of culture,
Thus there arise their corresponding institutions.
*Seeing simplicity and embracing purity,*
*Few private concerns and little desire.*

Once the names of learning and wisdom emerge,
Then the calamities of the world arise—
Better to reject and abandon them,
And the people will naturally benefit.
Once the names of benevolence and righteousness arise,
Then distinctions between filial and unfilial,
Kind and unkind, begin to emerge—
Better to reject and discard them,
And let the people forget the Dao,
Then all will return to the midst of filial piety and kindness,
Without any need for distinctions.

When cleverness and profit are valued,
Then thieves and robbers will arise—
Better to reject and abandon them,
This is what is meant by: *Do not esteem difficult-to-obtain goods,*
*So that the people will not become thieves.*

Learning and wisdom, benevolence and righteousness,
Cleverness and profit—
These three are all the Way of the world
Growing ever more refined and cultural,
Thus their names arise.
From the perspective of one who knows the Dao,
This refinement is not beneficial for governing the world—
Better to entrust the people,
And let them see simplicity and embrace purity,
Few private concerns and little desire,
Then the world will naturally have no troubles.

*Order* means *to make*;
*Entrust* is akin to the reading of *属民* in the *Rites of Zhou*.
This meaning is to say:
The more advanced the cultural governance,
The thinner the Way of the world becomes—
Better to return to simplicity and purity,
As in the age of antiquity.
This is also a speech of one’s time, filled with frustration at the world’s state.

**Chapter Twenty: Reject Learning, Worry Ceases**

chunks.original_text: 唯之与阿，相去几何？ 善之与恶，相去何若？ 人之所畏，不可不畏。 荒兮其未央哉。 众人熙熙，如享太牢，如登春台。 我独泊兮其未兆，若婴儿之未孩，乘乘兮若无所归。 众人皆有余，我独若遗，我愚人之心也哉，沌沌兮。 俗人昭昭，我独若昏； 俗人察察，我独闷闷。 澹兮其若海，飂兮似无所止。 众人皆有以，我独顽且鄙，我独异於人，而贵求食於母。 为道日损，为学日益，此等字义不可与儒书同，论学则离道矣。 绝学而归之无，则无忧矣。 唯、阿皆诺也。 人之学者以善为胜恶，是犹曰唯胜阿也，不若并善之名无之。 此即天下皆知美之为美，斯恶矣之意。 虽然古之知道者，虽以善恶皆不可为，而何尝无所畏。 凡人之所畏者，我未尝不畏之。 若皆以为不足畏，则其为荒乱何所穷极。 荒，乱也。 未央，无穷极也。 禅家曰豁达空拨因果，便是人之所畏而不畏也。 莽莽荡荡招殃祸，便是荒兮其未央哉。 众人之乐於世味也，如享太牢，如登春台，而我独甘守淡泊，百念不形，如婴兄未孩之时，乘乘然无所归止。 兆，形也，萌也。 此心不萌不动，故曰未兆。 婴，方生也。 孩，稍长也。 婴儿之心，全无知识。 乘乘，若动不动之意。 无所归，不着迹也。 此我之所以异於众人也，众人皆有求赢余之心，而我独若遗弃之，我岂愚而如此沌沌然乎？ 沌沌，浑沌无知之貌。 此意盖谓我之为道以不足为乐，而无有余之心，非我愚而汝智也。 昏昏闷闷，即沌沌是也。 俗人昭昭察察，而我独昏昏闷闷，此其所以异於人也。 其心淡泊，如乘舟大海之中，风飂然而无所止宿，此即乘乘若无归之意也。 有以，有为也。 众人皆有为，而我甘於不求，故若顽若鄙。 我岂真顽鄙哉？ 我之所以异於人者，味於道而已。 有名万物之母，母，即道也。 食，味也。 贵求食於母，言以求味於道为贵也。 道德真经口义卷之一 ＃１上善：原本作『小善』，据影日刊本改。 道德真经口义卷之二 鬳斋林希逸

**Chapter Twenty: Reject Learning, Worry Ceases**

*"Yes" and "Ah"*—how far apart are they?
*"Good"* and *"evil"*—how distant are they?

What people fear, I dare not fail to fear.
Oh, the chaos—its endlessness!

The multitude bustles, feasting as on a grand sacrifice,
Ascending spring platforms with joy.
Yet I alone remain still, unformed—
Like an infant yet to stir,
Drifting, drifting, as if nowhere bound.

The multitude all have excess;
I alone seem abandoned.
Ah, my foolish heart—so muddled!

The common man is bright and clear;
I alone seem dim.
The common man is sharp and keen;
I alone am dull and clouded.

Serene as the sea, yet restless as the wind,
Endless, with no place to rest.

The multitude all have their schemes;
I alone am stubborn and crude.
I differ from others—
Yet I prize savoring the Mother.

To practice the Dao is daily subtraction;
To study is daily addition.
These words must not be confused with Confucian texts—
For learning only distances one from the Dao.

Reject learning and return to the Uncarved,
Then there will be no worry.

*"Yes"* and *"Ah"* are both affirmations.
Men who study take *"good"* over *"evil"*—
Just as one might say *"Yes"* triumphs over *"Ah"*—
Yet it is better to discard even the name of *"good."*

This is the meaning: *"When all under heaven know beauty as beauty,
Then ugliness arises."*

Yet even the ancients who knew the Dao,
Though they deemed both *"good"* and *"evil"* unworthy,
Still had things they feared.
Whatever people fear, I have never failed to fear.

If I were to treat all fears as unworthy,
Then where would the chaos end?

Chaos—this is disorder.
Endless—without limit.

The Chan school speaks of sudden awakening,
Breaking through cause and effect—
This is the fear people have yet do not fear.

Wild and unrestrained, inviting calamity—
This is the *"Oh, the chaos—its endlessness!"*

The multitude delights in worldly flavors,
Feasting as on a grand sacrifice,
Ascending spring platforms—
Yet I alone take joy in simplicity,
No thoughts taking form,
Like an infant yet to stir,
Drifting, drifting, as if nowhere bound.

*Unformed*—this means no stirrings, no movement.
Thus, *"unformed."*

*Infant*—just born.
*Child*—slightly grown.
The heart of an infant knows nothing at all.

*Drifting, drifting*—as if motionless.
*Nowhere bound*—untouched by traces.

This is how I differ from the multitude—
They all seek gain and excess,
While I alone seem abandoned.
Am I truly foolish, so muddled?

*Muddled*—utterly confused, without knowledge.
This means I take no pleasure in excess,
Nor do I harbor thoughts of surplus—
Not because I am foolish, but because you are wise.

*Dim and clouded*—this is the same as *muddled.*
The common man is bright and sharp,
While I alone am dim and clouded—
This is how I differ.

My heart is serene, like a boat on the great sea,
The wind howling without rest—
This is the meaning of *drifting, drifting, as if nowhere bound.*

*Have schemes*—to act with purpose.
The multitude all act with purpose,
While I take joy in seeking nothing—
Thus I seem stubborn and crude.
Am I truly crude?

I differ from others only in savoring the Dao.

The Mother of ten thousand things—
*Mother*—this is the Dao.
*Food*—this is *savoring.*
To prize savoring the Mother—
This means to value tasting the Dao.

chunks.original_text: 孔德之容章第二十一 孔德之容，唯道是从。 道之为物，唯恍唯惚。 惚兮恍，其中有象； 恍兮惚，其织中有物。 窈兮冥兮，其中有精； 其精甚真，其中有信。 自古及今，其名不去，以阅众甫。 吾何以知众甫之然哉？ 以此。 孔，盛也。 知道之士，唯道是从，而其见於外也，自有盛德之容。 德之为言得也，得之於己曰德，道不可见而德可见，故以德为道之容。 孟子曰：动容周旋中礼，盛德之至。 与此句差异。 但读庄老者，当以庄老字义观之，若欲合之孔孟，则字多窒碍矣。 唯恍唯惚，言道之不可见也。 虽不可见而又非无物，故曰其中有象，其中有物，其中有精。 此即真空而后实有也。 其精甚真，其中有信，此两句发明无物之中，真实有物，不可以为虚言也。 信，实也。 道之名在於古今，一日不可去，而万善皆由此出。 众甫，众美也。 阅，历阅也。 万善往来，皆出此道也。 以此者，以道也。 言众甫之所自出，吾何以知其然，盖以此道而已。 此等结语，亦其文字之精处。 曲则全章第二十二 曲则全，枉则直，洼则盈，弊则新，少则得，多则惑。 是以圣人抱一为天下式。 不自见，故明； 不自是，故彰； 不自伐，故有功； 不自矜，故长。 夫唯不争，故天下、莫能与之争。 古之所谓曲则全者，岂虚言哉，诚全而归之。 能曲而后能全，能枉而后能直，能洼而后能盈，能弊而后能新，能少而后能多。 此皆能不足而后能有余，能真空而后实有之意。 少则得，多则惑，只是少则多三字，又细绎作两句也。 一者，虚也，无也，不足也。 圣人所抱只这一件道理，所以为天下之法式。 不自见、不自是、不自伐、不自矜，皆是不有其有之意。 我既虚心而无所争於天下，又何争之有？ 长、可久也。 既如此说了，却提起前面曲则全一句，作如此归结，亦是文之奇处。 天地之与我无所欠阙，我但当全而归之耳，又他何所事也。 ，诚者，实也，言实当如此也。 曲、枉、洼、弊四句皆是设喻，以发明下面之意而已。 希言自然章第二十三 希言自然。

「The Chapter on the Appearance of Great Virtue (Chapter 21)
The appearance of great virtue follows only the Dao.
The Dao as a thing—
Only vague, only indistinct.
Indistinct yet vague—
Within it lies an *image* (xiàng).
Vague yet indistinct—
Its *weaving* (zhī) contains *things* (wù).
Deep and dark—
Within it lies *essence* (jīng).
Its essence is most true,
Within it lies *faith* (xìn).
From ancient times to the present,
Its name does not fade,
For it encompasses all *beauties* (méi).
How do I know all beauties are thus?
Because of this.
*孔* (Kǒng), means *abundant* (shèng).
Those who understand the Dao,
Follow only the Dao,
Yet what they manifest outwardly—
They possess the appearance of abundant virtue.
*德* (Virtue) as a word means *obtain* (dé).
To obtain it from oneself is virtue.
The Dao is unseen, yet virtue is seen,
Thus virtue is called the appearance of the Dao.

Mencius said: *"When one’s movements and demeanor are measured and harmonious, that is the utmost of virtue."*
This sentence differs slightly.
But those who read Zhuangzi and Laozi,
Should observe them through the lens of their own words—
If one seeks to reconcile them with Confucius and Mencius,
Then the language becomes too constrained.

Only vague, only indistinct—
This speaks of the Dao’s unseen nature.
Though unseen, it is not without substance,
Thus it is said: *Within it lies an image,*
*Within it lies things,*
*Within it lies essence.*
This is the meaning of *true emptiness and then real existence.*

Its essence is most true,
Within it lies faith—
These two sentences reveal that within the void,
There is truly substance,
And this cannot be dismissed as empty words.
*信* (Faith) means *reality* (shí).

The Dao’s name persists through antiquity and modernity,
Never vanishing for a single day,
And all good things arise from it.
*众美* (All beauties) are the myriad virtues.
*历阅* (Encompassing) means to traverse and witness.
All good things come and go,
All from this Dao.
*以此者* (Because of this) means *because of the Dao.*
I know that all beauties originate thus—
It is because of this Dao alone.
This kind of concluding phrase
Is also the refined essence of the text.

**The Chapter on Flexibility and Fullness (Chapter 22)**
When *flexible* (qū), one is *whole* (quán);
When *crooked* (wǎng), one is *straight* (zhí);
When *hollowed* (wā), one is *filled* (yíng);
When *worn* (bì), one is *renewed* (xīn);
When *few* (shǎo), one *gains* (dé);
When *many* (duō), one is *bewildered* (huò).
Thus the Sage holds *oneness* (yī) as the model for all under heaven.
Not self-displaying, hence *bright* (míng);
Not self-asserting, hence *illustrious* (zhāng);
Not self-praising, hence *accomplished* (gōng);
Not self-exalting, hence *enduring* (cháng).

Only by not contending,
Is the Sage unmatched by all under heaven in contention.

The ancients spoke of *flexibility leading to fullness*—
Was this empty talk?
Indeed, it is fullness and return.

To be flexible and then whole,
To be crooked and then straight,
To be hollowed and then filled,
To be worn and then renewed—
To be few and then many—
All speak of the meaning:
*To be insufficient and then have abundance,*
*To be truly empty and then real existence.*

*Few yet gain, many yet bewildered*—
This is merely the phrase *few, many* (shǎo duō),
Further refined into two sentences.

*One* (yī) is the *void* (xū),
The *unseen* (wú),
The *insufficient* (bùzú).
The Sage holds only this principle of *oneness*,
Thus it becomes the standard for all under heaven.

Not self-displaying,
Not self-asserting,
Not self-praising,
Not self-exalting—
All mean *not claiming what one has.*

I, with an empty heart,
Contend with nothing under heaven—
Then what is there to contend?

*Enduring* (cháng) means *long-lasting* (kě jiǔ).
Having said this,
Yet it brings back the earlier phrase *flexibility leading to fullness*,
To conclude thus—
This is also a marvel of the text.

Heaven and Earth, with me,
Have no lack or defect—
I but return to fullness,
And what else is there to do?

*诚* (Indeed) means *reality* (shí).
The four sentences on *flexibility, crookedness, hollowness, and wear*
Are all parables,
To reveal the meaning below.

**The Chapter on Sparse Speech and Naturalness (Chapter 23)**
*Sparse speech* (xī yán) is *naturalness* (zìrán).*」

chunks.original_text: 故飘风不终朝，骤雨不终日。 孰为此者？ 天地。 天地尚不能久，而况於人乎？ 故从事於道者，道者同於道，德者同於德，失者同於失。 同於道者，道亦乐得之； 同於德者，德亦乐得之； 同於失者，失亦乐得之。 信不足，有不信。 天地之间，只自然两字可以尽天地之理。 希，少也。 谓此二字，其言不多，而天地之理不过如此而已。 飘风骤雨，虽天地为之，而亦不终朝，不终日，人之得丧穷达，又岂可常哉？ 从事於道者，言学道者也。 道，行也。 德，得也。 可行则行，我亦无违焉。 可得则得，我亦无违焉。 可失则失，我亦无违焉。 同者，随顺而无违之意。 可行我亦乐得之，可得我亦乐得之，可决我亦乐得之一行止得失，我皆乐之，此所以为知道之士。 然此事须信得及方可，若信处才有未足，则於此有不能一自信者。 故曰信不足，有不信。 跂者不立章第二十四 跂者不立，跨者不行，自见者不明，自是者不彰，自伐者无功，自矜者不长。 其在道也，曰余食赘行。 物故恶之，故有道者不处也。 足不着地曰跂，趺而立则不能久。 跨者，两股不相着也，跨则不可以行。 此两句是譬喻也。 自见、自是、自伐、自矜，皆是有其有而不化者。 不明，自蔽也。 不彰，名不显也。 不长，不可久也。 《易》曰：盈不可久也。 亦是此意。 余食赘行，皆长物也。 有道者无进，有逵则为长物矣。 曰余，曰赘，庄子骈拇枝指之意也。 食之余弃，形之赘疣，人必恶之，此有道者所以不处也，言不以迹自累也。 有物混成章第二十五 有物混成，先天地生，寂兮寥兮，独立而不改，周行而不殆，可以为天下母。 吾不知其名，字之曰道，强为之名曰大。 大曰逝，逝曰远，远曰反。 故道大，天大，地大，王亦大。 域中有四大，而王处一焉。 一人法地，地法天，天法道，道法自然。 有物混成，’道也，无极而太极也。 其生在天地之先，言天地自是而出也。 寂兮寥兮，不可见也。 独立而不改，常久而不易也。 周行而不殆，行健而不息也。 可以为天下母，天下万物之所由生也。 吾不知其名，不可得而名也。 名不可得，字之曰道。 字者，代冬之谓也。 。 曰道不足以尽之，又强而名之曰大。 大不足以尽之，又名之曰逝。 逝者，往也。 不可追逐也。 逝不足以尽之，又强而名之曰远。 远者，不可近也，不可得而亲附也。 远又不足以尽之，又强而名之曰反。 反者，复归於根之意也。 此皆鼓舞之文，在《庄子》此类尤多，或以反为反求诸身则非矣。 域中有四天，王居其一，盖言人居天地之间，但知有王之为大，而不知王之上，其大者又有三焉。 然而人则法地，地则法天，天则k 法道，道又法於自然，是自然又大於道与天地也。 其意但谓道至於自然而极，如此发挥，可谓奇论。 重为轻根章第二十六 重为轻根，静为躁君。 是以君子终曰行不离辎重。 虽有荣观，燕处超然。 如何万乘之主，而以身轻天下。 轻则失臣，躁则失君。 有重则有轻，有静则有躁。 根者，言轻自重而生也。 君者，言躁以静为主也。 有道之人，终日行而不着於辎重之间，言无重则无轻也，无静则无躁也。 离，丽也。 其胸中之所见，极天下之至美，故曰荣观。 虽有此荣观，而居之以安，故超然在於轻重静躁之外。

---

Thus, gusts of wind do not last the morning,
And sudden rains do not last the day.
Who does this?
Heaven and Earth.

Even Heaven and Earth cannot endure—
How much less can mortals?

Therefore, those who follow the Dao:
Those aligned with the Dao are one with the Dao,
Those aligned with virtue are one with virtue,
Those aligned with loss are one with loss.

Those one with the Dao—
The Dao delights in them;
Those one with virtue—
Virtue delights in them;
Those one with loss—
Loss delights in them.

Faith insufficient, there is doubt.
Between Heaven and Earth,
Only the two words *natural* and *sparse*
Can exhaust the principle of Heaven and Earth.

*Sparse*—few.
These two words, though few in speech,
Yet the principle of Heaven and Earth is no more than this.

Though gusts and sudden rains are wrought by Heaven and Earth,
They do not last the morning, nor the day—
How can human gain and ruin, rise and fall,
Be constant?

Those who follow the Dao—
They who study the Way.
The Way—action.
Virtue—attainment.
What may be acted upon, I act upon—
I do not resist.
What may be attained, I attain—
I do not resist.
What may be lost, I lose—
I do not resist.

*One*—to follow in harmony without resistance.
What may be acted upon, I delight in attaining;
What may be attained, I delight in attaining;
What may be decided—whether gain or loss—I delight in it all—
This is why they are called *knowers of the Dao*.

Yet this requires sufficient faith.
If faith is lacking where it should be,
Then one cannot fully trust oneself.

Thus it is said:
*Faith insufficient, there is doubt.*

**The Chapter on the Unsteady Not Standing (Chapter 24)**
The unsteady does not stand,
The straddling cannot walk.
The self-revealing are blind,
The self-righteous are unilluminated,
The self-praising achieve nothing,
The self-exalting do not endure.

In the Dao, they are called *excess food, superfluous limbs*.
Things naturally abhor them,
Thus the Daoist does not dwell upon them.

*Unsteady*—feet not touching the ground.
Standing on tiptoe, one cannot endure.
*Straddling*—thighs not touching.
Straddling, one cannot walk.
These two sentences are metaphors.

Self-revealing, self-righteous, self-praising, self-exalting—
All are those who claim what they have and do not transform.
*Unilluminated*—self-obscured.
*Unilluminated*—name not displayed.
*Not enduring*—cannot last long.

The *Yijing* says:
*"Fullness cannot endure long."*
This is the same meaning.

*Excess food, superfluous limbs*—
All are burdens.
The Daoist makes no progress;
Progress is a burden.
*Says excess, says superfluous*—
In the manner of Zhuangzi’s *conjoined toes, branched fingers*.
Food’s excess is discarded,
Form’s superfluity is a blemish—
Mankind naturally abhors them,
Thus the Daoist does not dwell upon them,
Saying: *Do not burden oneself with traces.*

**The Chapter on the Indiscernible Mixture (Chapter 25)**
There is a thing, mixed and complete,
Born before Heaven and Earth,
Silent and vast,
Standing alone yet unchanging,
Circulating yet without peril,
It can be the Mother of all under Heaven.

I do not know its name—
I call it the Dao.
Forcibly naming it, I say: *Great*.
*Great* says: *Passing*,
*Passing* says: *Distant*,
*Distant* says: *Returning*.

Thus, the Dao is great,
Heaven is great,
Earth is great,
The Sage is great.
Within the realm, there are four *Greats*—
And the Sage occupies one.

One follows Earth,
Earth follows Heaven,
Heaven follows the Dao,
The Dao follows Naturalness.

*There is a thing, mixed and complete*—
The Dao.
The *Unexcelled* and the *Supreme Polarity*.
Its birth precedes Heaven and Earth—
Saying Heaven and Earth arise from it.
*Silent and vast*—
Invisible.
*Standing alone yet unchanging*—
Enduring yet unaltered.
*Circulating yet without peril*—
Vigorous yet unceasing.
*It can be the Mother of all under Heaven*—
The source from which all things arise.

I do not know its name—
It cannot be named.
Since it cannot be named,
I call it the Dao.
*Call*—a substitute term.

*Says the Dao*—
Yet the Dao is insufficient to exhaust it,
So I forcibly name it *Great*.
*Great*—
Yet *Great* is insufficient to exhaust it,
So I name it *Passing*.
*Passing*—
Going, yet cannot be pursued.
*Passing*—
Yet *Passing* is insufficient to exhaust it,
So I forcibly name it *Distant*.
*Distant*—
Cannot be approached, cannot be clung to.
*Distant*—
Yet *Distant* is insufficient to exhaust it,
So I forcibly name it *Returning*.
*Returning*—
The meaning of returning to the root.

These are rhetorical flourishes—
In *Zhuangzi*, such abound.
Some mistakenly take *Returning* as *seeking within oneself*—
This is wrong.

*Within the realm, there are four Greats*—
The Sage dwells in one.
It means: though mankind resides between Heaven and Earth,
They know only the Sage as great,
Yet above the Sage, there are three greater still.

Yet one follows Earth,
Earth follows Heaven,
Heaven follows the Dao,
The Dao follows Naturalness—
Thus, Naturalness is greater than the Dao, Heaven, and Earth.

Its intent is but to say:
The Dao reaches its extreme in Naturalness—
Such is the marvelous argument.

**The Chapter on the Heavy as Light’s Root (Chapter 26)**
The heavy is the root of the light,
The still is the lord of the restless.

Thus the sage always says:
*"Action does not depart from the baggage train."*
Though there be splendid palaces,
He dwells aloof and serene.

How can the ruler of ten thousand chariots
Make his body light for all under Heaven?
Lightness brings loss of ministers,
Restlessness brings loss of the self.

There is heavy, there is light,
There is still, there is restless.
*Root*—
Saying lightness arises from heaviness.
*Lord*—
Saying stillness governs restlessness.

The Daoist, throughout the day,
Walks without clinging to baggage—
Saying: without heaviness, there is no lightness;
Without stillness, there is no restlessness.

*Depart*—
To adhere.
His mind’s vision reaches the utmost beauty of all under Heaven—
Thus *splendid palaces*.
Though such palaces exist,
He dwells in them with ease—
Thus, he stands aloof beyond lightness, heaviness, stillness, and restlessness.

To conclude thus—
This is also a marvel of the text.

Heaven and Earth, with me,
Have no lack or defect—
I but return to fullness,
And what else is there to do?

*诚* (Indeed) means *reality* (shí).
The four sentences on *flexibility, crookedness, hollowness, and wear*
Are all parables,
To reveal the meaning below.

**The Chapter on Sparse Speech and Naturalness (Chapter 23)**
*Sparse speech* (xī yán) is *naturalness* (zìrán).*」

chunks.original_text: 燕，安也。 处一居也，犹吾书所谓安行广居也。 为万乘之主，若不知身之为重， 则不能超然於事物之外，必至有轻躁之失。 失臣者，不足以臣服天下也。 失君者，言自失所主也。 以身轻天下者，言以天下为重，以身为轻也。 不轻其身则知道矣，知道则知自然矣，知自然则无静无重矣，而况有轻躁乎？ 善行无辙迹章第二十七 善行无辙迹，善言无瑕谪，善计不用筹策，善闭无关楗而不可开，善结无绳约而不可解。 是以圣人常善救人，故无弃人，常善教物，故无弃物，是谓袭明。 故善人，不善人之师； 不善人，善人之资。 不贵其师，不爱其资，虽智大迷，是谓要妙。 、 善言、善行、善计、善闭、善结，五者皆譬喻也。 其意但谓以自然为道，则无所容力，亦无所着迹矣。 圣人虽异於众人，而混然与之而处，未尝有自异之心，所以不见其迹也。 圣人之道，可以救人，可以救物。 其於人物也，亦甚异矣，而未尝有弃人弃物之心。 和光同尘而与之为一，故曰袭明。 袭者，藏也，袭明却庄子所谓滑疑之耀也。 善人可以师范一世，虽异於不善之人，而天下若无不善之人，则谁知善人之为善，是不善人乃为善人之资也。 资者，言其赖之以自别也。 此两句又发明上面无弃人无弃物之意。 若有弃人弃物之心，则是有师而不知贵，有资而不知爱，虽自以为智，而不知乃迷之大者。 知此道者，可谓要妙之道。 知其雄章第二十八 知其雄，守其雌，为天下溪。 为天下溪，常德不离，复归於婴儿。 知其白，守其黑，为天下式。 为天下式，常德不忒，复归於无极#1。 知其荣，守其辱，为天下谷。 常德乃足，复归於朴。 朴散则为器，圣人用之则为官长，故大制不割。 知雄守雌，不求胜也。 知白守黑，不分别也。 知荣守辱，无歆艳也。 知守有能为而不为之意。 溪谷在下，一水所归也，言如此则天下归之。 式，天下以为式也。 常德，即首章所谓常道也。 不离，无间断也。 不忒，无差失也。 乃足，备全之也。 婴儿，无知也。 无极，无物也。 朴#2 ，太朴也，天地之始也。 太朴既散，而后有器，即形而上谓之道，形而下谓之器也。 圣人以形而上者，用形而下者，则天地之间各有其职。 圣人兼三才，以御万物，虽职覆职载亦听命於我，是为天地之间，官於物者之长也。 庄子曰：官天地。 天地之职，亦造化之一官守耳。 割，离也。 以道制物谓之大制，大制则道器不相离矣。 此亦无为而为，自然而然之意。 将欲取天下章第二十九 将欲取天下而为之者，吾见其不得已。 天下神器，不可为也。 为者败之，执者失之。 凡物或行或随，或嘘或吹，或强或羸，或载或隳。 是以圣人去甚，去奢，去泰。 天下神器，岂人力所可得。 道盛德至，天下归之而不得辞，而后可以有天下。 若萌取天下之心，而强为善，以求有得，次不可得矣。 此三句是譬喻也，其意盖言凡天下之事，不可以有心求也。 为者则铃败，执者则必失，是皆有心之累也。 故有道者之於物，行者听其自行，随者听其自随，嘘者听其自嘘，吹者听其自吹，强者听其自强，羸者听其自羸，成者听其自成，隳者听其自隳，是皆自然而然而已。 行、随，犹先后也。 载，成也。 甚、奢、泰三者，皆过当之名，亦前章余食赘行之意。
chunks.translated_text:
「燕，安也。
*Yan* is tranquility.

处一居也，犹吾书所谓安行广居也。
To dwell in one place is to abide—
Just as my writings say: to walk in ease and dwell in breadth.

为万乘之主，若不知身之为重，
To rule the ten thousand chariots,
If one does not know the weight of the body—

则不能超然於事物之外，必至有轻躁之失。
Then one cannot stand aloof beyond things,
Surely falling into the faults of lightness and restlessness.

失臣者，不足以臣服天下也。
To lose ministers means
One cannot make all under Heaven submit.

失君者，言自失所主也。
To lose the self means
One has lost what one governs.

以身轻天下者，言以天下为重，以身为轻也。
To make the body light for all under Heaven—
This means to regard all under Heaven as weighty,
And the body as light.

不轻其身则知道矣，
If one does not slight the body,
Then one knows the Dao.

知道则知自然矣，
Knowing the Dao,
One knows spontaneity.

知自然则无静无重矣，而况有轻躁乎？
Knowing spontaneity,
There is neither stillness nor weight—
How much less restlessness and lightness?

**善行无辙迹章第二十七**
The chapter on *good walking leaving no tracks*—

善行无辙迹，
Good walking leaves no tracks,
善言无瑕谪，
Good speech has no flaws or blemishes,
善计不用筹策，
Good plans need no calculations or schemes,
善闭无关楗而不可开，
Good closure has no locks or bars yet cannot be opened,
善结无绳约而不可解。
Good binding has no cords or knots yet cannot be undone.

是以圣人常善救人，故无弃人，
Thus the sage always excels in saving others—
Therefore, he abandons no one,
常善教物，故无弃物，
Always excels in teaching things—
Therefore, he abandons no thing,
是谓袭明。
This is called *concealing brightness*.

故善人，不善人之师；
Thus the good person is the teacher of the not-good,
不善人，善人之资。
The not-good person is the material of the good.

不贵其师，不爱其资，
If one does not honor his teacher,
Or cherish his material—
虽智大迷，
Though wise, it is great confusion,
是谓要妙。
This is called *the essential subtlety*.

善行、善言、善计、善闭、善结，五者皆譬喻也。
Good walking, good speech, good plans, good closure, good binding—
These five are all metaphors.

其意但谓以自然为道，则无所容力，
Their meaning simply states:
If spontaneity is taken as the Dao,
Then there is no need to exert force—
亦无所着迹矣。
Nor to leave any traces.

圣人虽异於众人，而混然与之而处，
The sage, though different from the common folk,
Yet blends harmoniously with them in dwelling—
未尝有自异之心，
Never harboring a thought of self-difference,
所以不见其迹也。
Thus his traces are unseen.

圣人之道，可以救人，可以救物。
The sage’s Dao
Can save people, can save things.

其於人物也，亦甚异矣，
In its relation to people and things,
It is also very different—
而未尝有弃人弃物之心。
Yet the sage never has a heart to abandon people or things.

和光同尘而与之为一，故曰袭明。
He blends with the light and mingles with the dust,
Yet remains as one with them—
Thus it is called *concealing brightness*.

袭者，藏也，
*Concealing*—
This is *hiding*.
袭明却庄子所谓滑疑之耀也。
*Concealing brightness* is the opposite of Zhuangzi’s *shimmering doubt*—

善人可以师范一世，
The good person can serve as a model for the age—
虽异於不善之人，
Though different from the not-good—
而天下若无不善之人，则谁知善人之为善，
Yet if all under Heaven were not-good,
Who would know the good person’s goodness?
是不善人乃为善人之资也。
Thus the not-good person is the material for the good.

资者，言其赖之以自别也。
*Material*—
This means relying on it to distinguish oneself.

此两句又发明上面无弃人无弃物之意。
These two lines further elucidate
The meaning above of abandoning neither people nor things.

若有弃人弃物之心，
If one harbors a heart to abandon people or things—
则是有师而不知贵，
Then one has a teacher yet does not honor it,
有资而不知爱，
Has material yet does not cherish it—
虽自以为智，而不知乃迷之大者。
Though one may deem himself wise,
He does not know this is great confusion.

知此道者，可谓要妙之道。
He who knows this Dao
Can be called the *essential subtlety*.

**知其雄章第二十八**
The chapter on *knowing the masculine*—

知其雄，
Knowing the masculine,
守其雌，
And holding to the feminine—
为天下溪。
Makes one the valley of all under Heaven.

为天下溪，常德不离，
To be the valley of all under Heaven,
One’s constant virtue never departs—
复归於婴儿。
Returning again to the state of the infant.

知其白，
Knowing the white,
守其黑，
And holding to the black—
为天下式。
Makes one the pattern of all under Heaven.

为天下式，常德不忒，
To be the pattern of all under Heaven,
One’s constant virtue never errs—
复归於无极。
Returning again to the boundless.

知其荣，
Knowing the honor,
守其辱，
And holding to the humiliation—
为天下谷。
Makes one the valley of all under Heaven.

常德乃足，
One’s constant virtue is complete—
复归於朴。
Returning again to simplicity.

朴散则为器，
Simplicity disperses and becomes vessels—
圣人用之则为官长，
The sage uses them and becomes the ruler—
故大制不割。
Thus the great measure is not severed.

知雄守雌，不求胜也。
Knowing the masculine and holding to the feminine,
One does not seek to conquer.

知白守黑，不分别也。
Knowing the white and holding to the black,
One does not distinguish.

知荣守辱，无歆艳也。
Knowing the honor and holding to the humiliation,
One has no fondness for brilliance.

知守有能为而不为之意。
Knowing and holding implies
The power to act yet not acting.

溪谷在下，
The valley is low—
一水所归也，
Where waters converge—
言如此则天下归之。
Saying this, all under Heaven will follow.

式，天下以为式也。
*Pattern*—
This is what all under Heaven takes as its model.

常德，
Constant virtue—
即首章所谓常道也。
Is the *constant Way* spoken of in the first chapter.

不离，
Never departing—
无间断也。
Means no interruption.

不忒，
Never erring—
无差失也。
Means no deviation.

乃足，
Complete—
备全之也。
Is fully sufficient.

婴儿，
The infant—
无知也。
Is without knowledge.

无极，
The boundless—
无物也。
Is without things.

朴，
*Simplicity*—
太朴也，
This is *Great Simplicity*—
天地之始也。
The origin of Heaven and Earth.

太朴既散，而后有器，
Great Simplicity having dispersed,
Then vessels come into being—
即形而上谓之道，形而下谓之器也。
This is the Dao of *that which is above form*,
And vessels of *that which is below form*.

圣人以形而上者，用形而下者，
The sage uses *that which is above form*
And employs *that which is below form*—
则天地之间各有其职。
Thus between Heaven and Earth,
Each has its proper function.

圣人兼三才，
The sage encompasses the Three Powers—
以御万物，
To govern all things—
虽职覆职载亦听命於我，
Though functions overlap and shift,
They all obey his command—
是为天地之间，官於物者之长也。
Thus he is the ruler of all things
Between Heaven and Earth.

庄子曰：官天地。
Zhuangzi says: *He rules Heaven and Earth*.
天地之职，
The functions of Heaven and Earth—
亦造化之一官守耳。
Are but one aspect of the natural transformations.

割，
*Sever*—
离也。
Is separation.

以道制物谓之大制，
To govern things with the Dao is called *great measure*—
大制则道器不相离矣。
Great measure means the Dao and things do not separate.

此亦无为而为，自然而然之意。
This is also the meaning of *non-action yet action*,
And *spontaneity as it is*.

**将欲取天下章第二十九**
The chapter on *when one would take all under Heaven*—

将欲取天下而为之者，
When one would take all under Heaven by force—
吾见其不得已。
I see it as inevitable failure.

天下神器，
All under Heaven is a divine vessel—
不可为也。
Cannot be forced.

为者败之，
To force it is to ruin it,
执者失之。
To grasp it is to lose it.

凡物或行或随，
All things either move forward or follow—
或嘘或吹，
Either exhale or inhale—
或强或羸，
Either are strong or weak—
或载或隳。
Either are completed or destroyed.

是以圣人去甚，
Thus the sage avoids excess—
去奢，
Avoids extravagance—
去泰。
And avoids superfluity.

天下神器，
All under Heaven is a divine vessel—
岂人力所可得。
How can it be obtained by human strength?

道盛德至，
When the Dao flourishes and virtue reaches its peak—
天下归之而不得辞，
All under Heaven submits to it without refusal—
而后可以有天下。
Then one may truly possess all under Heaven.

若萌取天下之心，
If one harbors the thought of seizing all under Heaven—
而强为善，
And forcibly does good—
以求有得，
In order to gain—
次不可得矣。
Then one will surely fail.

此三句是譬喻也，
These three lines are metaphors—
其意盖言凡天下之事，
Their meaning is: all things under Heaven—
不可以有心求也。
Cannot be sought with a deliberate heart.

为者则铃败，
To force is to ring the bell of ruin,
执者则必失，
To grasp is to surely lose—
是皆有心之累也。
These are both burdens of the deliberate heart.

故有道者之於物，
Thus those who possess the Dao toward things—
行者听其自行，
Let those who move forward do so of their own accord,
随者听其自随，
Let those who follow do so naturally,
嘘者听其自嘘，
Let those who exhale do so spontaneously,
吹者听其自吹，
Let those who inhale do so freely,
强者听其自强，
Let the strong act as they will,
羸者听其自羸，
Let the weak be as they are,
成者听其自成，
Let the completed be so,
隳者听其自隳，
Let the destroyed be undone—
是皆自然而然而已。
All this is but spontaneity as it is.」

Saying lightness arises from heaviness.
*Lord*—
Saying stillness governs restlessness.

The Daoist, throughout the day,
Walks without clinging to baggage—
Saying: without heaviness, there is no lightness;
Without stillness, there is no restlessness.

*Depart*—
To adhere.
His mind’s vision reaches the utmost beauty of all under Heaven—
Thus *splendid palaces*.

chunks.translated_text:
「圣人去之者，
The Sage removes it—
无心无累，无为无求也。
Without deliberation or burden, without action or seeking.

此章结得其文又奇，
This chapter concludes its text with yet another marvel—
甚、奢、泰三字只是一意，
The three words *shen* (excess), *she* (extravagance), and *tai* (profligacy) all express one meaning,
但如此下语，
Yet they are stated in this manner—
非唯是其鼓舞之笔，
Not only to inspire and exhort,
亦申言其甚不可之意。
But also to emphasize how utterly unacceptable they are.

其言玄妙，
Its language is profound and mysterious—
则曰玄之又玄，
Then it speaks of *"xuan"* beyond *"xuan"*,
则曰大，曰逝，曰远，
Then it says *"da"* (vast), *"shi"* (flowing), *"yuan"* (distant),
皆是一样文法。
All following the same rhetorical structure.

读者不悟#3 其意，
Readers who do not grasp its meaning—
故不见他文字奇处，
Thus fail to see the brilliance of its other phrasing,
又多牵强之说。
And often resort to forced interpretations.

以道佐人主章第三十
Chapter Thirty: Aiding the Sovereign with the Dao—
以道佐人主者，
Those who aid the sovereign with the Dao—
不以兵强天下，
Do not impose upon the world with arms,
其事好还。
For their actions will return upon them.

师之所处，
Where the armies encamp—
荆棘生焉。
Thorns and brambles grow.
大军之后，
After great armies—
必有凶年。
There will surely be years of calamity.
故善者果而已矣，
Thus the virtuous act decisively—
不敢以取强焉。
Without daring to seize force.

果而勿矜，
Decisive yet not arrogant,
果而勿伐，
Decisive yet not boastful,
果而勿骄，
Decisive yet not proud,
果而不得已，
Decisive yet without compulsion,
果而勿强。
Decisive yet not forceful.
物壮则老，
All things, when at their peak, decline—
是谓非道，
This is called *not* the Dao,
非道早已。
And the Dao rejects such early.

佐人主而以强兵为心，
To aid the sovereign while harboring thoughts of military might—
则非知道者矣。
Is to not truly possess the Dao.

何者？
Why?
兵，凶器也。
Because arms are instruments of violence.
我以害人，
If I use them to harm others,
人亦将以害我，
Others will surely harm me in return—
故曰其事好还。
Hence it is said: *"their actions will return upon them."*

用师之地，
Where armies are deployed—
农不得耕，
Farmers cannot till the fields,
则荆棘生矣。
Then thorns and brambles grow.
用兵之后，
After wielding arms—
伤天地之和气，
The harmony of Heaven and Earth is disrupted,
则必有凶年之苜。
Then there will surely be years of calamity.

此意但言好战求胜，
This meaning simply states that those who love war and seek victory—
非国之福。
Are not blessings for the state.
七句只是譬喻。
These seven lines are but metaphors.

若人之为善，
If people act in virtue—
其果者在我，
Its results lie within themselves,
而何尝敢以此求胜於人，
And how could they dare to use this to seek victory over others?
故曰不敢以取强。
Hence it is said: *"Without daring to seize force."*

果，《易》言果行育德是也。
*"Fruit"* (果), as the *Yijing* speaks: *"Fruitful action nurtures virtue."*
其果者在我，
Its fruit lies within oneself—
而不形诸外，
Yet does not manifest outwardly,
则无矜伐骄强之名。
Thus there is no name of arrogance, boasting, pride, or force.
而其应事也，
And in responding to affairs—
常有不得已之意，
There is always the sense of *"not being able to help it,"*
此亦知雄守雌之论。
This is also the theory of *"knowing the strong yet holding to the weak."*

强者不能终强，
The forceful cannot persist in force,
矜者不能终矜，
The arrogant cannot persist in arrogance,
譬如万物既壮#4则老必至矣。
Just as all things, once at their peak, must decline.
不知此理，
Those who do not understand this principle—
而欲以取强於天下，
Yet wish to seize force in the world—
皆不道者也。
Are all those who do not possess the Dao.
既知此为不道，
If one knows this to be *not* the Dao—
则当急急去之，
Then one must urgently abandon it,
故曰早已。
Hence it is said: *"And the Dao rejects such early."*

已者，已而勿为也。
*"Early"* (已) means: *"Having reached the limit, do not act."*

夫佳兵章第三十一
Chapter Thirty-One: *"The Fine Art of War"*—
夫佳兵者，
Now, the fine art of war—
不祥之器，
Is an ill-omened instrument,
物或恶之，
Which things may detest,
故有道者不处。
Thus those who possess the Dao do not dwell upon it.

是以君子居则贵左，
Hence, the noble one values the left in dwelling—
用兵则贵右。
Yet values the right in wielding arms.
兵者，
Arms—
不祥之器，
Are ill-omened instruments,
非君子之器，
Not the instruments of the noble,
不得已而用之，
Used only when there is no alternative,
恬淡为上。
With equanimity as the highest.

故不美也，
Thus they are not beautiful—
若美必乐之，
If they were beautiful, one would surely delight in them,
乐之者是乐杀人也。
And delighting in them is delighting in killing.
夫乐杀人者，
Now, those who delight in killing—
不可得志於天下矣。
Cannot achieve their desires in the world.

故吉事尚左，
Thus auspicious matters are honored on the left,
凶事尚右。
And inauspicious matters on the right.
是以偏将军处左，
Hence, the subordinate general is placed on the left—
上将军处右，
While the supreme general is on the right,
言居上势则以丧礼处之。
Speaking of those in high positions as if they were in mourning.

杀人众多，
Many are killed—
以悲哀泣之。
With sorrowful tears.
战胜，
When victorious in battle—
以丧礼处之。
They are treated as if in mourning.

此章全是以兵为喻，
This entire chapter uses war as a metaphor—
兼当时战争之习胜，
And incorporates the prevailing customs of war at the time,
故以此语戒之。
Thus warning with these words.
佳兵，
*"Fine art of war"*—
喜用兵者也。
Refers to those who love to use arms.
以用兵为佳，
To consider wielding arms as fine—
此不祥之人也，
This is the mark of an ill-omened person,
以不祥之人而行不祥之事，
Who engages in ill-omened deeds as an ill-omened person—
故曰不祥之器。
Hence it is said: *"Arms are ill-omened instruments."*

此天下之所恶，
This is what the world detests,
故有道者不为之。
Thus those who possess the Dao do not do it.

且君子之居，
Moreover, in dwelling—
每以左为贵，
The noble always values the left,
而兵则尚右，
Yet arms are honored on the right,
便是古人亦以兵为不祥之事。
This shows that even the ancients regarded arms as inauspicious matters.
非君子之所乐用，
Not something the noble delights in using,
必不得已而后为之，
Used only when there is no alternative,
不幸而用兵，
If misfortune compels the use of arms—
必以恬淡为尚。
One must uphold equanimity.

恬淡，无味也，
*"Equanimity"* (恬淡) is flavorless—
即是不得已之意也，
It is the same as *"not being able to help it,"*
虽胜亦不以为喜。
Even if victorious, one does not take pleasure in it.
不美者，
*"Not beautiful"*—
言用兵不是好事也。
Means that wielding arms is not a good thing.
若以用兵为喜，
If one takes pleasure in wielding arms—
则是以杀人为乐，
Then it is to delight in killing,
岂能得志於天下。
How could one achieve their desires in the world?

孟子曰：不嗜杀人者能一之。
Mencius said: *"Those who do not delight in killing can unite the world."*
亦此意也。
This is the same meaning.

偏将军之职位本在上将军之下一
The subordinate general’s rank is naturally beneath that of the supreme general—
今上将军居右，
Yet now the supreme general is on the right,
而偏将军居左，
And the subordinate general is on the left,
是古人以兵为凶事，
This is because the ancients regarded war as an inauspicious matter,
故以丧礼处之。
Thus they treated it with funeral rites.

左，阳也。
The left is *yang*—
右，阴也。
The right is *yin*—
丧礼则尚阴，
Funeral rites are associated with *yin*,
幸而战胜，
Even if victorious in battle—
亦当以居丧之礼，
One should still observe mourning rites,
泣死者而悲哀之可也。
Weeping for the dead and expressing sorrow is proper.
以势而言，
In terms of rank—
下反居上，
The lower is paradoxically placed above,
故曰言居上势。
Hence it is said: *"Those in high positions as if in mourning."*

此章之意，
The meaning of this chapter—
盖言人之处世，
Is that in life—
有心於求胜者，
Those who harbor thoughts of seeking victory—
皆为凶而不为吉也。
Are all inauspicious, not auspicious.

道常无名章第三十二
Chapter Thirty-Two: *"The Dao Is Ever Nameless"*—
道常无名，
The Dao is ever nameless,
朴虽小，
Yet the primal simplicity, though small,
天下不敢臣。
The world does not dare to treat it as a subject.
侯王若能守，
If lords and kings can uphold it,
万物将自宾。
All things will naturally submit.

天地相合，
Heaven and Earth unite—
以降甘露，
To descend sweet dew,
人莫之令而自均。
Without anyone commanding, it is naturally balanced.

始制有名，
Only when names are first imposed—
名亦既有。
Names have already been given.
夫亦将知止，
Then one must also know when to stop—
知止所以不殆。
Knowing when to stop is how one avoids ruin.

譬道之在天下，
Just as the Dao exists in the world—
由川谷之於江海也。
Is like rivers and valleys to the ocean.

道常无名，
The Dao is ever nameless—
即可名非常名也。
Thus it can be named *"the nameless beyond names."*
无名之朴，
The nameless simplicity—
道也。
Is the Dao.
虽若至小，
Though it may seem the smallest,
而天下莫不尊之，
Yet the world does not fail to revere it,
孰敢卑之，
Who dares to belittle it?
故曰不敢臣。
Hence it is said: *"The world does not dare to treat it as a subject."*

为侯王者若能守此道，
If lords and kings can uphold this Dao—
则万物自宾服之矣。
Then all things will naturally submit to them.

天至高也，
Heaven is supremely high—
下而接乎地，
Yet descends to meet the Earth,
天气下降，
Heaven’s *qi* descends,
地气上腾，
Earth’s *qi* ascends—
而后甘露降焉。
Then sweet dew descends.
天地和，
When Heaven and Earth are in harmony—
则甘露降。
Then sweet dew descends.
民之在天下，
The people in the world—
自生自养，
Naturally give birth and nurture themselves,
莫不埤平，
All things are balanced,
谁实使之，
Who truly commands it?
自然之道也。
It is the Dao of nature.

chunks.translated_text:
若容心而使，则不得其均平矣。
If one indulges the heart’s desires in governance, balance cannot be achieved.

道之始，本无名焉，万物既作，而后有道之名。
At its origin, the Dao was nameless—
Only after all things took form did it receive the name "Dao."

制，作也，是朴散而为器也。
*"Zhi"* means to shape—
This is when the undifferentiated simplicity (*pu*) disperses to become things.

此名既有，则一生二，二生三，何所穷已。
Once named, it gives rise to two from one,
Three from two—
Where does it end?

知道之士，当於此而知止，则不循名而逐末矣。
Those who understand the Dao must know when to stop here,
Lest they follow names and chase after trivialities.

循名逐末，则危殆之所由生也，知止则不殆矣。
Chasing after names and trifles breeds peril—
Knowing when to stop brings safety.

川谷之水，铃归之江海而后止；
The waters of streams and valleys
Flow toward the seas and only then find rest—
天下万物，必归之道而后止。
All things under Heaven
Must return to the Dao before finding rest.

故曰道之在天下，犹川谷之於江海也。
Hence it is said: *"The Dao’s place in the world
Is like streams and valleys to the seas."*

---
知人者智章第三十三
**Chapter 33: The Wise Know Others**

知人者智，自知者明。
To know others is wisdom,
To know oneself is enlightenment.

胜人者有力，自胜者强。
To overcome others requires strength,
To overcome oneself is true power.

知足者富，强行者有志。
Contentment brings wealth,
Persistent action reveals resolve.

不失其所者久，死而不亡者寿。
Whoever remains in their proper place endures—
To die without perishing is true longevity.

智，私智也。
*"Wisdom"* here means discerning others’ hidden motives.

明，在内者也。
*"Enlightenment"* is self-awareness within.

有力，角力於外者也。
*"Strength"* is outward struggle against others.

强，在内之果也。
*"True power"* is the fruit of inner mastery.

自胜者强，胜己之私谓之克也。
To conquer oneself is true power—
Overcoming personal desires is victory.

知足者富，无不足则常有余也。
Contentment is wealth—
Wanting nothing ensures abundance.

志胜气则其强也不弱，
When resolve overcomes *qi*, strength is unyielding—
得其所安则久而不变，
Finding true rest ensures enduring stability—
故曰不失其所者久。
Hence it is said: *"Whoever remains in their proper place endures."*

孔子曰：朝闻道，夕死可矣。
As Confucius said:
*"To hear the Dao in the morning,
Death at dusk would be no loss."*

死而不亡者寿，
To die without perishing is true longevity—
亦此意也。
This carries the same meaning.

此二句非言语所可解，自证自悟可也。
These two lines cannot be fully explained in words—
Self-verification and awakening suffice.

---
大道泛兮章第三十四
**Chapter 34: The Great Dao Flows**

大道泛兮，其可左右。
The Great Dao flows unrestrained,
Moving without favor to left or right.

万物恃之以生而不辞，
All things rely on it for life, yet it does not refuse—
功成不居，
It accomplishes without claiming—
衣被万物而不为主，
It clothes all things yet claims no lordship—
故常无欲，可名於小矣；
Thus it ever desires nothing,
And may be called "small"—
万物归焉而不知主，可名於大矣。
Yet all things return to it, unaware of any master,
And so it may be called "great."

是以圣人能成其大也，
Thus the Sage achieves greatness—
以其不自大，故能成其大。
Because they do not exalt themselves,
They alone achieve true greatness.

泛兮其可左右，
Flowing without constraint,
无所系着也。
It clings to nothing.

物物皆道之所生，
All things are born of the Dao—
何尝辞之。
How could it refuse them?

既生矣，何尝居之以为功。
Once born, how could it claim them as its own deeds?

衣被，蒙赖也。
*"Clothing"* means covering and nurturing—
万物皆蒙赖其利，
All things benefit from its grace—
而道何尝有主宰之心，
Yet the Dao harbors no lordly intent—
湛然而无所欲，
Serene and desiring nothing—
可谓之自小矣，
Thus it may be called "small"—
故曰可名於小。
Hence it is named "small."

道虽小，而万物归之以为主，
Though the Dao is small,
All things return to it as their master—
道亦不自知，
Yet it knows not itself—
岂不谓之大乎？
How then is it not called "great"?

惟其能小，所以能大，
Only by being small
Can it achieve greatness—
圣人之所以不为大者，故能成其大也。
The Sage does not claim greatness,
And thus achieves true greatness.

此即守其雌，为天下溪之意。
This is the meaning of *"embracing the feminine"* and *"being a valley to the world."*

---
执大象章第三十五
**Chapter 35: Grasping the Great Image**

执大象，天下往。
Hold fast to the Great Image,
And all under Heaven will follow.

往而不害，安平泰。
Following without obstruction,
They find peace, balance, and ease.

乐与饵，过客止。
Offer music and feasts,
And passing guests will linger.

道之出言，淡乎其无味。
The Dao’s words, when spoken,
Are bland, without relish.

视之不足见，听之不足闻，
To look upon it is unsatisfying,
To listen is unfulfilling—
用之不可既。
Yet its use is inexhaustible.

大象者，无象之象也。
The "Great Image" is the form of the formless—
天下往者，执道而往行之天下也。
Those who follow are those who uphold the Dao in their actions.

以道而行，则天下孰得而害之。
Acting in accordance with the Dao,
Who under Heaven could harm them?

天下无所害，则安矣，平矣，泰矣。
Without harm in the world,
They are at peace, balanced, and at ease.
三字亦只一意也。
These three words convey a single meaning.

乐，钟鼓之乐也。
*"Music"* refers to ceremonial bells and drums—
饵，饮食也。
*"Feasts"* means food and drink.
张乐设馔以待嘉客，
Setting out music and banquets to welcome honored guests—
乐终食尽，客过则止矣。
When the music ends and the feast is done,
Guests depart.

过者，去也，
*"Over"* means to leave—
是筵席必有散时也。
Banquets must eventually conclude.

道之可味，虽若甚淡，
Though the Dao’s flavor seems bland—
视之虽不可见，
Though it cannot be seen—
听之虽不足闻，
Though it cannot be heard—
言其不足悦耳目也，
This is because it does not please the senses—
而用之於今古而不尽。
Yet its use spans past and present without end.

此即物有尽而道无穷之意。
This conveys the idea that *"things are finite, but the Dao is boundless."*

道之出言，道形於言也，
The Dao’s words are its manifestation in speech—
犹曰道之为言也。
As if to say: *"The Dao’s name."*

---
将欲噏之章第三十六
**Chapter 36: Before Taking Away**

将欲噏之，必固张之；
Before you can gather,
You must first stretch it taut—
将欲弱之，必固强之；
Before you can weaken,
You must first strengthen—
将欲废之，必固兴之；
Before you can discard,
You must first establish—
将欲夺之，必固与之，
Before you can take,
You must first give—
是谓微明。
This is called *"subtle enlightenment."*

柔之胜刚，弱之胜强。
Softness overcomes hardness,
Weakness overcomes strength.

鱼不可脱於渊，
Fish cannot escape the depths—
国之利器，不可以示人。
Nor should a nation’s sharpest tools be displayed to all.

此章前八句皆是譬喻，
These first eight lines are all metaphors—
只是得便宜处失便宜之意。
Illustrating the principle of *"gaining advantage by first yielding advantage."*

噏，敛也，弛也。
*"Nyon"* means to gather or relax—
张者必弛，
What is stretched must relax—
强者必弱，
What is strong must weaken—
兴必有废，
What is established must decay—
得必有失。
What is gained must be lost.

与，得也。
*"Give"* means to grant—
夺，失也。
*"Take"* means to deprive.

人#5 惟不知，自以为喜，
#5 People, in their ignorance, take pleasure—
而不知此理虽晦而实明，
Yet they fail to see that though this principle seems obscure,
故曰微明#6。
It is truly enlightening.

微，犹晦也，
*"Subtle"* is like *"obscure"*—
言虽微而甚易见也。
Saying that though subtle, it is easily perceived.

但能柔弱，必可以胜刚强，
Only by embracing softness and weakness
必可以胜刚强，
Can one overcome hardness and strength—
此亦守雌守黑之意。
This too is the meaning of *"embracing the feminine and the dark."*

渊，喻道也。
*"The depths"* symbolize the Dao—
鱼，喻人也。
*"Fish"* symbolize people.
人之不能外於道，犹鱼之不可脱於渊也。
Just as people cannot exist outside the Dao,
So fish cannot escape the depths.

国之利器，若以示人，盗贼之招也。
A nation’s sharpest tools,
If displayed to others, invite thieves.

道之为用在我，
The Dao’s power lies within—
若自眩露而以求胜於物，
Yet if one flaunts it to outdo others—
亦犹以国之利器而示人也。
It is like displaying a nation’s sharpest tools.

此亦前章善者果而已，不可以取强之意。
This too echoes the earlier idea:
*"The good are content with their harvest—
They do not seek to dominate."*

---
道常无为章第三十七
**Chapter 37: The Dao Ever Does Nothing**

道常无为，而无不为。
The Dao ever does nothing,
Yet nothing remains undone.

侯王若能守，万物将自化。
If lords and kings could uphold it,
All things would transform of their own accord.

化而欲作，吾将镇以无名之朴。
When transformation stirs to action,
I would restrain it with the nameless simplicity.

无名之朴，亦将不欲，
The nameless simplicity would also desire nothing—
不欲以静，
Desiring nothing, it would remain still—
天下将自正。
And the world would naturally align itself.

此章与道常无名章语势皆同。
This chapter’s structure mirrors *"The Dao Ever Has No Name."*

天至高也，

chunks.original_text: 无为无不为，自然而然也。 侯王若能守此无为之道，则不求化万物，而万物自化矣。 天地之间，万化欲作之时，吾但峡无名之朴镇之。 化，万物之变也。 万变俱作，相寻不已，而我但以自然处之。 彼自纷纷，我自安安，故曰镇。 下句化字，不可拈上句化字说。 无名之朴，何也？ 亦无欲而已。 无欲则静，静则天下自正矣。 不欲即无欲也，不字又有勿字意，用功处也。 道德真经口义卷之二竟 #1复归於无极：原本脱『归』字，据影宋本加。 #2也、朴：此两字原脱，据影宋本加。 #3悟：原本作『悮』，据影宋本改。 #4壮：原本作『往』，据影宋本改。 #5人：原本衍一『人』字，据影宋本删。 #6故曰微明：原本脱『微明』二字，据影宋本加。 道德真经口义卷之三 鬳斋林希逸
chunks.translated_text:
The Dao does nothing yet does everything—
This is the natural way of things.

If lords and kings could uphold this Dao of non-action,
They would not strive to transform all things,
Yet all things would transform on their own.

Between Heaven and Earth, when transformations stir to rise,
I would only restrain them with the nameless simplicity.

Transformation is the change of all things.
When myriad changes arise together,
Endlessly pursuing one another,
I would simply abide in the natural way.

They grow tumultuous, yet I remain serene—
Thus it is called *restraint*.

The "transformation" in the latter clause
Should not be read as echoing the "transformation" above.

What is this "nameless simplicity"?
It is simply the absence of desire.

Without desire, there is stillness;
With stillness, the world naturally aligns itself.

"Not desiring" is the same as "without desire,"
Yet the "not" also carries the meaning of "do not"—
This is where effort is applied.

#3 *"Awaken"*—Original text read *"anxious"* (corrected from *Shadow Song Edition*).
#4 *"Vigorous"*—Original text read *"go"* (corrected from *Shadow Song Edition*).
#5 *"People"*—Original text erroneously duplicated *"people"* (omitted per *Shadow Song Edition*).
#6 *"Thus it is called subtle clarity"*—Original text omitted *"subtle clarity"* (added from *Shadow Song Edition*).

chunks.original_text: 上德不德章第三十八 上德不德，是以有德； 下德不失德，是以无德。 上德无为而无以为，下德为之而有以i 为。 上仁为之而无以为，上义为之而有．以为。 上礼为之而莫之应，则攘臂而仍之。 故失道而后德，失德而后仁，失仁而后义，失义而后礼。 夫礼者，忠信之薄而乱之首也。 前识者，道之华，而愚之始也。 是以大丈夫处其厚，不处其薄； 居其实，不居其华。 故去彼取此。 上德之人，有德而不自知其德化也，惟其能化，是以有德。 不失德者，执而未化也。 执而未化，则未可以为有德，故曰无德。 上德下德，只前章太上其次之论。 无为而无以为，即无为而无不为也。 以者，有心也。 无以为，是无心而为之也。 下德之有以为，则为容、心矣。 既言上德下德，又以仁义继之。 上仁为之而无以为，以仁为上德也。 上义为之而有以为，以义为下德也。 老子之学，以礼为强世，先以仁义抑扬言之，而后及於礼，则礼为愈下矣。 为之而莫之应，强民而民不从之也。 仍，引也。 民不从而强以手引之。 强，掣拽之也。 只是形容强民之意，故曰攘臂而仍之。 道，自然也。 德，有得也。 自然者化，有得者未化，故曰失道而后德。 仁者有爱利之心，比之德又下矣。 义者有断制之心，比之仁又下矣。 礼者有强民之意，比之义又下矣。 老子之言仁义礼，其字义皆与孔孟不同，就其书而求其意可也。 若论正当字义，则皆失之。 礼者，忠信之薄，言修饰於外而不由中矣。 其意以礼为出於人伪，故曰乱之首。 前识者，多识前言往行也。 以多识为智，射非道之实矣。 华者，务外也。 若以此为智，反以自愚，故曰愚之始。 曰厚、曰实，只是务内之意。 去彼取此者，言其不为礼而为道也。 此者，道也。 昔之得一章第三十九 昔之得一者，天得一以清，地得一以鸟宁，神得一以灵，谷得一以盈，万物得一以生，侯王得一以为天下贞。 其致必之一也，天无以清将恐裂，地无以宁将恐发，＂神无以灵将恐歇，谷无以盈将恐竭，万物无以生将恐灭，侯王无以为贞而贵高将恐蹶。 故贵以贱为本，高以下为基。 是以侯王自称孤、寡、不谷，此其以贱为本邪？ 非乎？ 故致数车无车，不欲球球如玉，落落如石。 一者，道也。 天之所以清明而垂象，地之所以安静而载物，神之所以虚而灵，谷之所以虚而盈，皆此道也。 万物之所以生亦此道也，侯王之所以保正万邦亦此道也。 其致之者，言其清宁灵盈生正，皆因此道而得之。 裂，犹《周易》言段也。 发，言动而不定也。 歇，消灭而不灵也。 竭，尽也。 虚则能受，不虚则尽，止而不可受矣。 蹶，类也，处贵高之位而无此，则类蹶矣。 曰贱、曰下即前章所谓少则得之意，皆虚而不自有也。 贵贱高下两句，亦只是譬喻。 无贱何以为贵，无下何以能高，下与贱乃贵高之基本也。 侯王之称曰孤、曰寡人、曰不谷，皆是自卑之辞，又以此为虚而不自有之喻。 非乎者，言我如此说，岂有不然者乎？ 庄子曰：非乎而曾史是也。 亦是此类文势，此两字文之奇处。 数车无车一本作数誉无誉，誉字误也。 此两句本是譬喻，若作誉字，则与下文如玉如石意不相属矣。 致，至也，故致犹曰其至也。 车者，总名也。 随件而数之，则为轮、为毂、为辐、为衡、为轼，遂无车矣，车遂为虚名矣。

**Volume Three: *The Daoist Classic’s Oral Commentary***

---

**Chapter Thirty-Eight: *"The Virtue/Power of the Non-Ultimate"***

The Virtue/Power of the Non-Ultimate does not cling to virtue/power—
Thus it has virtue/power.
The virtue/power of the Lowly does not lose virtue/power—
Thus it lacks virtue/power.

The Virtue/Power of the Non-Ultimate acts without effort yet nothing remains undone;
The virtue/power of the Lowly acts with effort yet something remains incomplete.
The Virtue/Power of the Highest Benevolence acts without effort yet nothing remains undone;
The Virtue/Power of the Highest Righteousness acts with effort yet something remains incomplete.
The Virtue/Power of the Highest Ceremony acts with effort yet none respond—
Then they roll up their sleeves and force it upon them.

Thus, one loses the Dao/Way and then gains virtue/power,
Loses virtue/power and then gains benevolence,
Loses benevolence and then gains righteousness,
Loses righteousness and then gains ceremony.

Ceremony is the thin veneer of loyalty and trustworthiness,
And the beginning of chaos.
Preemptive knowledge is the adornment of the Dao/Way,
And the origin of folly.

Thus, the true person dwells in substance, not in veneer;
Dwells in reality, not in adornment.

Hence, they abandon the latter and take the former.

The person of the Non-Ultimate’s Virtue/Power possesses virtue/power yet does not know their own transformative power—
Only their ability to transform is why they have virtue/power.
Those who do not lose virtue/power cling to it without transformation—
Clinging without transformation is not yet virtue/power,
Hence it is called lacking virtue/power.

The Virtue/Power of the Non-Ultimate and the Lowly are merely the continuation of the previous chapter’s discussion on the *Taishang*’s Way.

*"Acts without effort yet nothing remains undone"* means *"acts without effort yet nothing is left undone."* (i)
The *"for"* (以) is the presence of intention.
*"Nothing remains undone"* is acting without intention.

The Lowly’s *"something remains incomplete"* is the result of deliberate action—
Of form and contrivance.
Having spoken of the Non-Ultimate’s and the Lowly’s virtue/power,
He then follows with benevolence and righteousness.

*"The Virtue/Power of the Highest Benevolence acts without effort yet nothing remains undone"*—
This is benevolence as the Non-Ultimate’s virtue/power.
*"The Virtue/Power of the Highest Righteousness acts with effort yet something remains incomplete"*—
This is righteousness as the Lowly’s virtue/power.

The Master Laozi’s teachings regard ceremony as a means to strengthen the world,
First using benevolence and righteousness to modulate and balance its application,
Then proceeding to ceremony—
Thus ceremony is the most inferior of the three.

To act yet meet no response is to compel the people while they do not follow—
*Reng* (仍), to draw or pull.
The people do not follow, yet they are compelled by force.
*Reng* is the act of forcibly drawing or pulling.
This is merely a vivid description of compelling the people—
Hence it is said: *"They roll up their sleeves and force it upon them."*

The Dao/Way is natural.
Virtue/Power is what is obtained.
The natural transforms, the obtained does not—
Hence it is said: *"One loses the Dao/Way and then gains virtue/power."*

Benevolence has the heart of love and benefit,
And is yet lower than virtue/power.
Righteousness has the heart of judgment and restraint,
And is yet lower than benevolence.
Ceremony has the intention of compelling the people,
And is yet lower than righteousness.

The Master Laozi’s terms for *ren* (benevolence), *yi* (righteousness), and *li* (ceremony)
Differ in meaning from those of Confucius and Mencius—
One may seek their intent within his text.
If one insists on their conventional meanings,
Then they are all misapplied.

Ceremony is the thin veneer of loyalty and trustworthiness—
It speaks of outward adornment without inner sincerity.
Its intent is that ceremony arises from human artifice,
Hence it is called the beginning of chaos.

Preemptive knowledge is the accumulation of past words and deeds.
To take this as wisdom is to stray from the true Dao/Way.
*Hua* (华) is the pursuit of externals.
If one takes this as wisdom, it is in fact self-delusion—
Hence it is called the origin of folly.

*"Substance"* and *"reality"* are merely the intent of pursuing the inner.
*"Abandon the latter and take the former"* means one does not adhere to ceremony but to the Dao/Way.
This is the Dao/Way.

---

**Chapter Thirty-Nine: *"The One of Old"***

The One of Old—
Heaven obtains the One and thus becomes clear,
Earth obtains the One and thus becomes settled and tranquil,
The spirit obtains the One and thus becomes responsive and alive,
The grain obtains the One and thus becomes full,
All things obtain the One and thus come to life,
The lords and kings obtain the One and thus establish their rectitude over the world.

Their attainment is all through the One—
Heaven without the One would fear dissolution,
Earth without the One would fear upheaval,
The spirit without the One would fear stagnation,
The grain without the One would fear exhaustion,
All things without the One would fear annihilation,
The lords and kings without the One would fear losing their noble standing.

Thus, the noble depends on the humble as its root,
The high depends on the low as its foundation.

Hence, the lords and kings call themselves *"lonely"* (孤), *"few"* (寡), *"not abundant"* (不谷)—
Is this their dependence on the humble as root?
Or is it not?

Thus, they have many chariots yet no chariots,
Do not desire to be rounded like jade,
Nor to be polished like stone.

The One is the Dao/Way.
Heaven’s clarity and the manifestation of its forms are through this Dao/Way,
Earth’s tranquility and its capacity to bear all things are through this Dao/Way,
The spirit’s responsiveness and vitality are through this Dao/Way,
The grain’s fullness and abundance are through this Dao/Way—
All are through this Dao/Way.

All things’ coming to life is also through this Dao/Way,
The lords and kings’ rectitude over the myriad lands is also through this Dao/Way.
Their attainment is through this Dao/Way—
This is why they become clear, tranquil, alive, full, and rectified,
All through this Dao/Way.

*Lie* (裂) is akin to *"breaking"* in the *Zhouyi* (I Ching) as *"segmented."*
*Fa* (发) is movement without stability.
*Xie* (歇) is the fading of responsiveness and vitality.
*Jie* (竭) is exhaustion.
The empty can receive—
The unempty is exhausted and thus cannot receive.

*Ju* (蹶) is akin to *"falling"* or *"losing one’s place."*
To be in a noble and high position yet lack this is to be like the fallen—
Hence it is said: *"The noble and high would fear losing their standing."*

The humble and the low are as the previous chapter’s *"few, yet they obtain it"*—
All are empty yet not self-possessed.

The two sentences on *"the noble depends on the humble"* and *"the high depends on the low"*
Are mere metaphors.
Without the humble, how can there be the noble?
Without the low, how can there be the high?
The low and the humble are the fundamental basis of the noble and the high.

The lords and kings’ self-designation as *"lonely"* (孤), *"few"* (寡人), *"not abundant"* (不谷)
Are all words of self-humility,
And also metaphors for emptiness without self-possession.

*"Or is it not?"* (非乎) asks:
If I say this, is there not truth in it?
Zhuangzi said: *"‘Or is it not?’—Yet the historian Zengzi agreed!"*
This is of the same rhetorical style,
A peculiar turn in the text.

*"They have many chariots yet no chariots"*—
Originally read *"They have many praises yet no praises"* (数誉无誉),
But *"praise"* (誉) is incorrect.
These two sentences are metaphors—
If read as *"praise,"* they do not align with the later imagery of *"like jade"* and *"like stone."*

*Zhi* (致) means *"to arrive at"* or *"to attain,"*
Hence *"their attainment"* is akin to *"their reaching this state."*
The chariot is a collective term—
Counting its parts—wheels, hubs, spokes, shafts, and crossbars—
Then there is no chariot,
The chariot becomes merely a hollow name.

The state of being like jade or like stone—
then it shines with a *lingling* brilliance,
falls with a *luoluan* resonance,
and is ultimately unchangeable.

A chariot may be had or not had,
but jade and stone are fixed and unchangeable.
That which may be had or not had
approaches the Dao—
empty yet transformative.

That which is fixed and unchangeable
does not transform.

Zhuangzi said: *"To say ‘no years’"*—

**Chapter Forty: The Movement of the Dao Through Reversal**
Reversal is the Dao’s dynamic principle,
weakness is the Dao’s application.

All things arise from existence,
existence arises from non-existence.

Reversal means return,
means stillness—
stillness is the source from which movement arises,
as in the *Yijing*’s saying:
*"Guàn completes the end and begins the beginning."*

Only by being weak can one become strong;
to fixate on strength is to break.

Movement employs stillness as its function,
strength employs weakness as its function—
thus it is said:
*Reversal is the Dao’s dynamic principle,*
*weakness is the Dao’s application in strength.*

Such phrasing follows grammatical structure.

Only after Heaven and Earth do all things exist—
thus it is said: *"Things arise from existence."*
Yet who gave birth to Heaven and Earth?
Heaven and Earth first arose from the Great Void—
thus they arise from non-existence.
Through movement, stillness, strength, and weakness,
the origin of existence and non-existence is further expounded.

The teachings of Laozi
largely emphasize emptiness,
emphasize weakness,
emphasize lowliness—
thus, extending this to the space between Heaven and Earth,
he speaks broadly of existence, non-existence, movement, and stillness,
yet does not limit himself to Heaven and Earth alone.

**Chapter Forty-One: The Superior Man Hears the Dao**
The superior man hears the Dao,
diligently practices it;

chunks.original_text: 中士闻道，若存若亡； 下士闻道，大笑之，不笑不足以为道。 故建言有之：明道若昧，夷道若类，进道若退，上德若谷，大白若辱，广德若不足，建德若偷，质真若渝，大方无隅，大器晚成，大音希声，大象无形，道隐无名。 夫惟道，善贷且成。 勤而行者，言闻而必信也。 若存若亡者，且信且疑，又以为有、又以为无也。 最下鄙俚之人，则直笑之耳。 惟最下之人以之为笑，方见吾道之高。 退之论文且曰：人笑之则以为喜，况道乎？ 建言者，立言也，言自古立言之士有此数语，明道若昧以下数句是也。 此亦是设辞，言此数句不出於我，自古有之也。 明道若昧，惟昧则明。 前章曰自见者不明，又曰不自见故明，即此也。 进道若退者，能退则为进也。 杨子所谓以退为进也。 夷，平也。 夷道，大道也，大道则无分别。 类，同也，和光同尘之意也。 上德若谷，能虚而不自实也。 大白若辱，不皎皎以自异也。 广德若不足，若自足则狭矣。 偷，窃也，欲为而不敢为也。 建立其德，是有为者而为之，以不敢为所以能建立也。 质真若渝，真实之质，纯一而无变，而自有若已渝变之意，此亦足而不自足之意。 大方者，太虚也，太虚之间虽有东西南北，孰见其方隅哉？ 大器晚成，如铸鼎之类，岂能速就哉？ 大音希声，天地之间音之大者，莫大於风霆，岂常有哉？ 希者，不多见也。 大象，天地也。 《易》曰：法象莫大於天地。 天地之形，谁得而尽见之？ 道隐无名，不可得而名也。 此数句，或是指实之语，或是譬喻之语，其意皆主於能虚能无而已。 贷者，与也，推以及人也，有道者能以与人而不自有也。 成者，道之大成也，成己成物，而后谓之大成也。 后章又曰：既以与人，己愈多。 亦此意也。 道生一章第四十二
chunks.translated_text:
「中士闻道，若存若亡；
The middle-ranking man hears the Dao,
as if it were both present and absent.

下士闻道，大笑之，不笑不足以为道。
The inferior man hears the Dao,
and laughs greatly at it—
for if he does not laugh,
it is not worthy to be called the Dao.

故建言有之：
Thus, it is said:

明道若昧，
The Dao is bright as if in darkness—
for only in darkness does brightness shine.

夷道若类，
The Great Dao is smooth as if blending with the common—
for the Great Dao knows no distinctions,
and harmonizes with the dust of the world.

进道若退，
Advancing in the Dao appears as retreat—
for true retreat is the path to true progress.

上德若谷，
The highest virtue is deep as a valley—
for it is empty yet not self-asserting.

大白若辱，
The greatest purity is stained as dishonor—
for it does not gleam ostentatiously to set itself apart.

广德若不足，
Vast virtue seems insufficient—
for if it were self-sufficient,
it would be narrow indeed.

建德若偷，
Establishing virtue appears as furtive—
for it is done by those who act,
yet hesitate lest they be seen.

质真若渝，
Pure authenticity seems to flow like water—
for its true and unchanging essence
holds no trace of alteration,
yet appears as if already transformed.
This too is the meaning of sufficiency without self-sufficiency.

大方无隅，
The greatest square has no corners—
for within the Great Void,
though there be east, west, south, and north,
who can discern its boundaries?

大器晚成，
Great vessels take time to form—
like casting a tripod,
how could it be swiftly completed?

大音希声，
Great sound is rare in voice—
the greatest sounds between Heaven and Earth
are none greater than wind and thunder,
yet they are not always heard.
Rare means seldom seen.

大象无形，
Great form is shapeless—
for the form of Heaven and Earth,
who can fully perceive?

道隐无名，
The Dao is hidden and nameless—
for it cannot be captured by name.

此数句，或是指实之语，或是譬喻之语，其意皆主於能虚能无而已。
These words,
whether pointing to reality or using metaphor,
all emphasize the power of emptiness and non-attachment.

贷者，与也，推以及人也，
*Acquiring* means giving—
to extend and share with others,
for those who embody the Dao
can give without possessing.

成者，道之大成也，
*Completion* is the great fulfillment of the Dao—
fulfilling oneself and all things,
and only then is it called great fulfillment.

后章又曰：既以与人，己愈多。
As the next chapter states:
*"After giving to others,
one’s own abundance increases."*
This too reflects the same meaning.

chunks.original_text: 道生一，一生二，二生三，三生万物。 万物负阴而抱阳，冲气以为和。 人之所恶，唯孤、寡、不谷，而王公以为称。 故物或损之而益，益之而损。 人之所教，亦我义教之。 强梁者，不得其死。 吾将以为教父。 一，太极也。 二，天地也。 三，三才也。 言皆自无而生。 道者，无物之始，自然之理也。 三极既立，而后万物生焉。 万物之生，皆抱负阴阳之气，以冲虚之理行乎其间，所以为和也。 人之所恶，莫如孤、寡、不谷，而王公以为称，此亦譬喻有道者自卑自贱之意。 其意盖谓天地人皆自无而有，万物以阴阳为质，而其所以生生者，皆冲虚之和气。 学道者当体此意，则必以能虚能无为贵。 天下之物，或欲损之而反以为益。 或欲益之而反以为损，损益之理，有不可常。 如月盈则必缺，此益之而损也。 既缺则又盈，此损之而益也。 人之所教，犹言今世人之所以设教，彼亦曰，我之所教，皆义理也。 但知求益，但知求胜，而不知刚者叉折，盈不可久，故曰强梁者不得其死也。 若吾以道教之，则皆在众人之上，是世之所师者。 又当以我为师也，故曰吾将以为教父。 天下之至柔章第四十三 天下之至柔，驰骋天下之至坚。 无有入於无间，是以知无为之有益也。 不言之教，无为之益，天下希及之矣。 坚者易折，柔者常存。 以至柔而行於至坚之间，如水之穿石是也。 无间，无缝坛也。 无有，即无形也。 如人身营卫之间。 可谓无间，而气脉得行之。 无隙之隙，而日月之光亦入之。 此皆无有入於无间也。 此两句譬喻也。 以此而观，则知无为无不为者至理也。 不言而教自行，无为而功自成，此皆至道之妙用，而天下之人知不及之，故曰：天下希及之。 有益，有功用也。 名与身章第四十四 名与身孰亲？ 身与货孰多？ 得与亡孰病？ 是故甚爱必大费，多藏必厚亡。 知足不辱，知止不殆，可以长久。 名货皆外物也，无益於吾身，则虽得虽亡，何足为病。 而不知道者，每以此自病。 爱有所着，则必自费心力以求之，爱愈甚，则费愈大，此言名也。 贵而多藏，一旦而失之，其亡也必厚。 无所藏则无所失，藏之少则失亦少，多藏乃所以厚亡也。 此二句发明下三句也。 惟知足者不至於自辱。 知止者不至於危殆，如此而后可以长久。 此三句，却是千古万古受用不尽者。 大成若缺章第四十五 大成若缺，其用不敝。 大盈若冲，其用不穷。 大直若屈，大巧若拙，大辩若讷。 躁胜寒，静胜热，清静为天下正。 有成则有缺，大成者常若缺，则其用不敝矣。 有盈则有虚，大盈者常若虚，则其用不穷矣。 前章曰洼则盈、敝则新即此意。 大直则常若屈然，枉则直也。 曲则全也。 大巧者常若拙然，不自矜也。 太辫者常若讷然，不容言也。 躁之胜者，其极必寒。 静之胜者，其极必热。 躁静只是阴阳字，言阴阳之气滞於一偏，皆能为病。 惟道之清静，不有不无，不动不静，所以为天下之正，犹曰为天下之式也。 天下有道章第四十六 天下有道，却走马以粪； 天下无道，戎马生於郊。 罪莫大於可欲，祸莫大於不知足，咎莫大於欲得。 故知足之足，常足。 以善走之马却以粪田，即不贵难得之货之意。 戎马生於郊，言争战也。 战争之事，皆自欲心而始，欲心既萌，何时而足？

**Chapter Forty-Three: The Dao Gives Birth to One**
The Dao gives birth to One,
One gives birth to Two,
Two gives birth to Three,
Three gives birth to the myriad things.
The myriad things bear yin while embracing yang,
and their harmonizing *qi* arises from their interplay.

What people detest—
the solitary, the widowed, the childless—
are the very titles kings and nobles claim.
Thus, some things are diminished to grow,
and others are increased to diminish.

What people teach as doctrine,
is also my teaching of *yi* (rightness).
The overbearing shall not meet a natural end.
I shall take this as my guiding principle.

One is the *Tai Ji*.
Two is Heaven and Earth.
Three is the Three Powers.
All speech arises from the void.

The Dao is the origin of all things,
the natural principle of spontaneity.
Once the Three Powers are established,
then the myriad things are born.

The myriad things take form through yin and yang,
and their vitality flows through the harmonizing *qi* of emptiness.
What people detest most—
the solitary, the widowed, the childless—
are titles kings and nobles adopt,
a metaphor for those who embody the Dao in humility and selflessness.

Its meaning is this:
Heaven, Earth, and humanity all arise from non-being.
The myriad things take yin and yang as their substance,
and their eternal generation comes from the harmonizing *qi* of emptiness.
Those who study the Dao must embody this—
valuing emptiness and non-attachment above all.

In the world, some things are diminished to grow,
and others are increased to diminish—
the principle of gain and loss is not constant.
Like the moon, when full it must wane—
this is growth leading to loss.
When waned, it swells again—
this is loss leading to growth.

What people teach as doctrine
refers to the teachings of this age,
yet they say: *"My teachings are all of rightness."*
But those who seek only gain,
who seek only victory,
know not that the rigid breaks,
that fullness cannot endure.
Thus, the overbearing shall not meet a natural end.

If I teach through the Dao,
I shall stand above all others—
the model all should follow.
Thus, I say: *"I shall be their guiding teacher."*

---

**Chapter Forty-Four: The World’s Ultimate Softness**
The world’s ultimate softness
overcomes the world’s ultimate hardness.
Nothing enters where there is no gap—
thus one knows the benefit of *wuwei*.

The teaching of the unsaid,
the benefit of *wuwei*—
few in the world can attain it.

The rigid is easily broken;
the soft endures forever.
To move through the world’s ultimate hardness with ultimate softness—
like water wearing away stone.

*"No gap"* refers to the seamless *tan* (altar).
*"Nothing enters"* means formlessness—
like the circulation of *yingwei* (nutritive and defensive *qi*) within the body,
or the unbroken spaces where sunlight enters.
This is *"nothing entering where there is no gap."*
These two lines are metaphorical.

From this, one understands
the supreme principle of *wuwei* as *wuwei* yet *wuwei* as *youwei*.

The unsaid yet teaching takes effect,
the undone yet benefits are achieved—
these are the wondrous applications of the Dao.
Few in the world can comprehend them.

*"Benefit"* means functional efficacy.

---

**Chapter Forty-Five: Great Fullness as if Deficient**
Great fullness seems deficient—
its use is inexhaustible.
Great abundance seems empty—
its use is boundless.
Great straightness seems crooked,
great skill seems clumsy,
great eloquence seems inarticulate.

Excessive vigor overcomes cold,
excessive stillness overcomes heat—
clearing and stillness are the world’s norm.

When fullness exists, deficiency follows.
Great fullness ever seems deficient—
thus its use is inexhaustible.
When abundance exists, emptiness follows.
Great abundance ever seems empty—
thus its use is boundless.

As the previous chapter states:
*"Hollowed becomes full,
worn becomes renewed"*—
this is the same meaning.

Great straightness ever seems crooked—
crookedness is true straightness.
The curved preserves completeness.
Great skill ever seems clumsy—
it does not boast.
Great eloquence ever seems inarticulate—
it does not speak much.

Excessive vigor reaches cold,
excessive stillness reaches heat.
Vigor and stillness are but yin and yang—
when *qi* stagnates in one extreme, it becomes a disorder.
Only the Dao’s clearing and stillness,
neither being nor non-being,
neither motion nor stillness,
is the world’s true norm—
the model for all under Heaven.

---

**Chapter Forty-Six: When the World Embraces the Dao**
When the world embraces the Dao,
even swift horses plow fields.
When the world rejects the Dao,
warhorses breed in the suburbs.

No guilt is greater than craving,
no disaster than insatiability,
no blame than greed.
Thus, true sufficiency is always sufficient.

To drive swift horses backward to till fields—
this means not valuing rare goods.
Warhorses breeding in the suburbs—
this speaks of warfare.

All conflicts arise from desire.
Once desire takes root,
when will it ever be enough?

**Chapter Forty-Six (continued): On the Pursuit of Desire**
Only the pursuit of what one *desires* is the root of guilt, disaster, and blame.
Only those who *know sufficiency* regard what they lack as enough—
then they are always sufficient.
This further elucidates the previous chapter’s meaning of *knowing sufficiency* without humiliation.

**Chapter Forty-Seven: Knowing Without Venturing Forth**
Not venturing beyond one’s door,
yet knowing all under Heaven;
Not peering through a window,
yet seeing the Dao of the world.
The farther one goes,
the less one knows.
Thus, the Sage does not move yet knows,
does not see yet names,
does not act yet accomplishes.
Though the world be vast,
the emotions of humanity and the principles of things are but one—
one can know them even without stepping beyond one’s door.
Though the Dao of the world be subtle,
the transformations of yin and yang
remain constant through the ages—
one can perceive them even without peering through a window.
If one must venture forth to seek them,
then what one reaches is limited,
and what one knows is few.
The eye’s range is limited,
and what one sees is few.
The more one exerts,
the more one’s mind grows dim—
thus it is said: *the farther one goes, the less one knows*.
This is also a metaphor to clarify the following verse.

Not moving yet knowing,
not seeking to see yet having a name,
not acting yet accomplishing—
this is the Sage’s Dao,
and thus its application.

The *Yijing* says:
*"Swift without haste, arriving without moving."*
This too conveys the same meaning.

**Chapter Forty-Eight: Daily Learning Increases**

chunks.original_text: 为学日益，为道日损。 损之又损，以至於无为，无为而无不为矣。 故取天下者，常以无事，及其有事，不足以取天下。 为学则日日求自益，为道则日日求自损。 故前言绝学无忧，盖言道不在於见闻也。 《大慧》云：读书多者，无明愈多。 亦此意也。 黜聪明，隳肢体，去智与故#1，则损之又损，则可以无为无不为矣。 取天下者秘以无心，有心者反失之。 三代之得天下，何容心哉？ 因当时战争之俗，借以为喻，其言亦足以戒，此书多有此意。 无事有事，即无心有心也。 圣人无常心章第四十九 圣人无常心，以百姓心为心。 善者吾善之，不善者吾亦善之，得善矣。 信者吾信之，不信者吾亦信之，得信矣。 圣人之在天下惵惵，为天下浑其心。 百姓皆注其耳目，圣人皆孩之。 无常心者，心无所主也。 以百姓之心为心，则在我者无心矣。 善不善在彼，而我常以善待之，初无分别之心，则善常在我。 在我之善，我自得之，故曰得善矣。 子曰：苟志於仁矣，无恶也。 与此意同。 信不信者在彼，而我常以信待之，初无疑间之心，则信常在我。 在我之信，我自得之，故曰得信矣。 子曰：不亿不信。 亦此意也。 其曰吾亦善之、亦信之者，非以其不善为善，非以其不信为信也，但应之以无心而已。 惵惵，不自安之意。 圣人无自矜自足之心，故常有不自安之意。 浑其心者，浑然而不露圭角。 此心浑然，所以无善不善、信不信之分也。 注其耳目者，人皆注其视听於圣人，而圣人皆以婴儿待之，故曰皆孩之。 此无弃人之意也。 出生入死章第五十 出生入死。 生之徒十有三，死之徒十有三，民之生，动之死地亦十有三。 夫何故？ 以其生生之厚。

**Chapter Forty-Nine: The Sage’s Heart is Without Fixed Attachment**

To learn is to daily gain,
To cultivate the Dao is to daily lose.
Lose and lose again,
Until one reaches *wuwei*—
*Wuwei*, yet nothing remains undone.
Thus those who take the world
Always act with *wuwei*—
But once they have *shi*,
They are no longer fit to take the world.

To learn is to daily seek self-benefit,
To cultivate the Dao is to daily seek self-loss.
Hence the earlier saying: *“When learning ceases, worries end”*—
For the Dao does not lie in perception or hearing.

The *Dàhuì* states:
*“The more one reads, the more *wúmíng* one has.”*
This too conveys the same meaning.

Discard cleverness,
Abandon the body’s strength,
Banish knowledge and old habits#1—
Then lose and lose again,
And one may attain *wuwei* and *wuwei* yet nothing undone.

Those who take the world conceal *wuxin*,
For those with *xin* will lose it again.
How could the Three Dynasties#2 have held the world with *xin*?

Using the customs of their time—
Warfare as metaphor—
Their words suffice as warning,
For this book often holds such meaning.

*Wuwei* and *shi* are the same as *wuxin* and *yǒuxin*.

**Chapter Fifty: The Sage’s Heart Embodies Life and Death**

Life and death intertwined.
Those who cling to life—thirteen in ten,
Those who cling to death—thirteen in ten,
Yet among the people,
Those who live are thrust into *sǐdì*#3—thirteen in ten.

Why is this so?
Because of the excess of their *shēngshēng*#4.
